div1.head: Notes on Gustaf E. Lambert, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, [November 1946]
div1.p:
Memorandum in re
The Statement of Gustaf E. Lambert, one time Pvt. H. C. at
Columbia Bks. Cuba-

It is quite natural for a man who has done his duty
bravely and faithfully in a difficult and dangerous
situation, when he sees other men who had acted their
parts, rewarded, while he is commended only but gets
us substantial reward, is left out to have a grievance. If he broods over it, the
situation becomes intolerable and he loses sight of the
essential conditions of such rewards- Facts are forgitten
or twisted out of true relation and he feels that an injustice
has been done him- Such seems to be the case with Mr Lambert.
When Congress in 1929 passed a bill giving pensions & medals
to the list of men who had been instrumental in the Reed
demonstration of the agency of the mosquito in transmitting yellow
fever the list was prepared for the H R committee by the
Surgeon General of the Army after a consultation with Gen
Kean and several of his assistants- Walter Reed and
the members of his Board, the nine men who underwent
the very repulsive fomites experiments and the American
volunteers who suffered attacks of yellow fever from experiments
with infected mosquitoes & blood injections were included- But
it was realized that doctors and nurses who exposed themselves
in the care of yellow fever cases in the line of duty should
not be included in the list, however meritorious their
services had been- The reason was obvious: there would
have been no limit to such a list-

The object of the legislation was to reward those who actively
participated in the experimental work- Those who cared for
the sick or disinfected their clothes as a measure of routine
sanitation were not included- These conditions excluded
Dr. Roger Post Ames, and Privates Lambert, Springer and a
number of others, who sought by special legislation to
have their names placed on the Yellow Fever Roll of
Honor- No applicant who was bitten but not infected was
ever included, nor any man whose exposure was not gov-
erned by the strict limitations of quarantine - and scientific control.
The efforts to disregard these necessary limitations have been
numerous and some of them absurd, as in the case of a
New York member of the H. R. who proposed as an additional
member of the Roll of Honor an estimable doctor who
had never been connected in any way with the work of the
Yellow Fever Board, but had been on duty at Camp Mon-
tock on Long Island treating the returning soldiers of the
Santiago Campaign in 1898-

So much for the claims put forward in this statement
of Gustaf Lambert, which seem worthy of a serious answer-
The statement is however clouded by numerous errors and
misstatements of which I will only notice a few, the object
of which is not to advance the claim of the writer but to
discredit me- I became ill of yellow fever before the Reed
Board arrived in Cuba, namely June 21, 1900- and
was treated in the a small hut in Yellow Fever section of
the Post Hospital at Columbia Barracks, His account of
my conversation and behavior is, as I recollect, without any
3
foundation in fact- I have never expressed nor even felt
any dissatisfaction with my treatment during my illness-
I certainly did not ask to have Lambert relieved from care
of me and certainly did not have him sent away from
Columbia Bks- He stated that he was sent away from
Columbia Bks about the end of August 1901- But I ceased
to be Chief Surgeon where Gen Fitzhugh Lee's Dept. was abolished about
Nov. 15, 1900 and I went to duty of Gen. Wood's staff in May 1901
so I had no connection whatever with movements of Personnel
at Columbia Bks after the latter date- I am equally innocent
of moving Dr. Ames away from Columbia Bks. In fact
my impression has been that he remained there until he
was sent by War Dept Order to Fort McIntosh Texas-
I has always entirely approved of his professional care of
me and entertained him at my house-

As regards his army record I know of nothing to his discredit
except the experimental inpection of Private Daniel L. Dris-
coll Co. F. 26 Inf at Fort McIntosh Texas Nov. 9, 1903 by means
of an infected mosquito- This did not advance in my way scientific
knowledge of an already established fact, while it endan-
gered a soldier's life and resulted in his permanent dis-
ability and discharge from the service- It was not not
however held against his claim to be included on the Yellow
Fever Roll of Honor, for he never so far as I know ever made
any such claim- Such a claim was made after his death by his
widow but was disapproved by the Surgeon General of the Army
on the ground that he had not become elegible, having been neither
a member of the Yellow Fever Board nor having been a case for
experiment by the Board- Of course I never was Surgeon General or
Acting Surgeon General of the Army nor did I have any personal
prejudice against Dr. Ames-,
